stream_context.summary: Kaze focused on refining the 3D layout and scale of the main overworld, blocking out key areas like the Yoshi Village and Bowser's level entrance. A significant portion of the stream was dedicated to the first steps of texturing this overworld, leading to a technical deep-dive into creating a complex sand material. Throughout, Kaze discussed a major off-stream achievement: a complete rewrite of the SM64 sound engine.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has completely rewritten the Mario 64 sound engine, resulting in massive performance gains, a smaller code footprint, and expanded capabilities for musical complexity.
development_findings.quote: The sound engine is now around 80% faster than vanilla sound engine. The code is around a quarter of the size. We need much less memory. And we support 32 notes instead of 16.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is actively shaping the overworld by adding large geographical features like mountains to break up space and is intentionally maintaining messy geometry to allow for easier iteration.
development_findings.quote: I think maybe it would be better if I actually had some proper mountain region here... We are keeping a lot of unnecessary triangles around so we can edit this level more in the future.

development_findings.summary: Kaze developed a complex multi-texture blending technique using combiners and vertex colors to overcome the N64's texture format limitations, allowing for detailed sand effects that can be artistically controlled.
development_findings.quote: You see how the detail is now all there? But we can control like how much of it shows up.

development_findings.summary: Kaze's level design process begins with a 2D sketch before he moves into 3D blockouts, even for a level as complex as the overworld.
development_findings.quote: I always sketch my level first, I guess.

development_findings.summary: The project is in a stage of rapid geometrical iteration, meaning that detailed visual work like final UV mapping and texturing is intentionally postponed to avoid wasted effort.
development_findings.quote: We're still on the stage where we're making a lot of rapid changes. So finalizing any visuals right now would be very stupid. Be a waste of time.

development_findings.summary: Kaze has developed a new random number generation algorithm for the game that incorporates real-world entropy, which he plans to feature in an upcoming YouTube video.
development_findings.quote: The next video is going to be about RNG in Mario 64 and how to improve it... finding a new RNG algorithm that uses real-world entropy as well.

development_findings.summary: Kaze is still actively debugging his new custom sound engine, identifying a bug where sounds would cut out when specific custom enemies performed an action.
development_findings.quote: I noticed what the issue with the coin salt here was. It's whenever the Goomba bunnies jump all sound sees. Look at this, this is what the bug is.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes his high productivity comes from utilizing free time that most people waste, rather than possessing a unique ability to find time.
context_findings.quote: If you think about your day-to-day, I'm sure you'll find that you waste most of your free time. And that's why you don't have time to do stuff like this. That's not meant as a front... this is just something general about humans.

context_findings.summary: Kaze holds a design philosophy that games should allow players to experience the world after they've saved it, rather than resetting to a pre-final boss state.
context_findings.quote: You know what I kind of don't like in video games? The fact that you spend the whole video game saving the world. But then once you save the world, you're not allowed to explore the saved world... I want the player to save the world and then be like, yep, this is the world now. You saved it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is strategically planning the game's release to avoid any proximity to official Nintendo announcements or game launches, fearing legal repercussions or being shut down.
context_findings.quote: I can't release this around the same time as Nintendo releases anything... Because if I do they will literally kill me. So if I release this I have to find a period of time where Nintendo is not dropping any big announcement or releases.

context_findings.summary: Creating sponsored YouTube content is a significant time investment for Kaze, requiring nearly two full days of work per video even with an editor.
context_findings.quote: I have to work almost like two days to make a video. And that is with an editor.

context_findings.summary: Kaze acknowledges that the project's public perception is heavily focused on technical optimization, a direction influenced by what content performed well on YouTube rather than his original intentions.
context_findings.quote: It's kind of weird to me that this whole project became so much about optimization in the public eye. But I guess it was bound to happen. That's just what did well on YouTube, and that's why I kept engaging with that.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is self-aware of his past actions being perceived as 'insane' and doesn't shy away from this characterization.
context_findings.quote: I have done plenty of insane shit in the past.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is considering a future where the project could be made 'legal', which would necessitate replacing all remaining vanilla assets, like textures.
context_findings.quote: If I want this to all be legal, I would technically need custom textures for everything. But that's something for later if I actually do want to make this a legal game or something.

context_findings.summary: Kaze describes his decision to move to Canada to be with his now-wife Zeina as impulsive and pragmatic, having moved without ever visiting the country beforehand.
context_findings.quote: I think we first started talking like early 2020 and then I moved to Canada in November 2021... I hate traveling so we made her visits and stats and then I moved right away without ever visiting.

biobak.summary: Biobak is creating a large number of custom textures for the game, though not every texture is custom yet.
Kaze notes there are still many levels that require a visual rework from Biobak, indicating a significant amount of graphical work remains.
Biobak provides not only assets but also tools to Kaze, such as a Blender plugin to improve the UV mapping workflow.
biobak.quote: I need the UV mapping plugin that Biobak sent me a couple days ago

badub.summary: Badub (referred to as 0VALT) has composed at least 12 different music tracks for the overworld level alone.
badub.quote: I have to open a music I've never made that's such a bop. But I do made around 12 OVALT songs. And this is the current version that 0VALT is working on right now.

badub.summary: The overworld music composed by Badub is designed to dynamically fade between different tracks as the player moves through different areas of the level.

zeina.summary: Kaze casually shares stream chat interactions with Zeina via direct messages during development, indicating a close and informal communication style.
zeina.quote: Yeah, I just copy pasted your text and put it in Zane's DMs.

zeina.summary: Kaze reveals he and Zeina married as a practical solution to simplify the immigration process for his move to Canada.
zeina.quote: I also just went to Canada and married Zaynab it was just easier that way.

key_stories.title: The Sound Engine Rewrite
key_stories.summary: Feeling constrained by the original game's audio limitations, Kaze undertook a complete rewrite of the Super Mario 64 sound engine. The result is a far superior system that is 80% faster and supports more complex music, directly enabling a richer audio experience for the project.
key_stories.challenge: The original Super Mario 64 sound engine was limiting, supporting only 16 notes at once, making complex music difficult, and it was notoriously hard to add new sound effects to.
key_stories.process: Over the course of a week, Kaze reverse-engineered and completely rewrote the game's sound engine from scratch. This involved deep analysis of the original code to build a new system that was more efficient and flexible.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze created a new, highly optimized sound engine that is faster, lighter, and doubles the note polyphony. This technical breakthrough unlocks greater creative freedom for composer Badub and allows for a richer soundscape in the game.
key_stories.key_quote: The sound engine is now around 80% faster than vanilla sound engine. The code is around a quarter of the size. We need much less memory. And we support 32 notes instead of 16.

key_stories.title: Solving the Bland Sand
key_stories.summary: Faced with making a large sand area look good on N64 hardware, Kaze went beyond simple texturing. He developed a sophisticated material using hardware-specific features to solve color banding issues and give himself artistic control over the sand's graininess, turning a boring flat area into a dynamic surface.
key_stories.challenge: A large sandy area in the overworld looked flat, repetitive, and visually uninteresting. Furthermore, the N64's low-precision texture formats (I4) caused any subtle details in textures to be lost to quantization, appearing as ugly color banding.
key_stories.process: Kaze experimented with different textures before realizing the issue was technical, not just artistic. He devised a complex material using the N64's hardware 'combiner'. This setup blends two textures and uses mathematical tricks to rescale the color range, preserving detail. He then used vertex color alpha to control the blend, allowing him to 'paint' detail levels directly onto the map.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze created a visually appealing and dynamic sand effect. He can now artistically control the graininess and smoothness of the sand across the terrain, solving both the aesthetic and technical challenges.
key_stories.key_quote: The detail is all there now. This way, instead of like a lot of coarseness on the small range, we have the coarseness on a much, on a much bigger range, right? The opposite.

key_stories.title: The Hackamari64 Rivalry
key_stories.summary: Kaze detailed his growing frustration with the alternative 'Hackamari64' project. He criticized their technical decisions and what he perceives as hypocrisy, establishing a clear philosophical divide between the two major decompilation-based modding efforts.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze holds a strong negative opinion of Hackamari64, a parallel Mario 64 decompilation project, creating a sense of rivalry or ideological opposition within the modding community.
key_stories.process: Kaze observed the Hackamari64 project over time. He found their design choices 'weird', noted they broke compatibility with the original game (e.g., the camera), and took issue with their complaints about his code's complexity, especially when he felt their own practices (like using an uneditable binary blob for a bootloader) were worse.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze has solidified his position as a self-professed 'hater' of the Hackamari64 project, believing their development practices are flawed and hypocritical, reinforcing his confidence in his own project's direction and technical foundation.
key_stories.key_quote: They kept complaining that they can't have my code because my code is too difficult to understand... And then after doing that, saying that my code is hard to edit, then it shouldn't be in. Come on. The hypocrisy.
